reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central move in the post: rejecting CES-based ρ estimates as “heroic extrapolation” while still offering a confident-ish range for ρ (≈[-0.2,0]) and dismissing low implied max-speeds as “implausible.” If that epistemic move is undermined, the post’s quantitative confidence about when compute bottlenecks bite is weakened (centrality ~0.6), though it doesn’t directly refute many other listed counterarguments (e.g., experiment efficiency gains, alternative research routes), so it’s not fully position-collapsing. The argument has moderate strength: it credibly points out an asymmetry/selection problem in how extrapolation skepticism is applied, but it doesn’t show that the author’s non-econometric considerations are valueless or equally unreliable, nor does it engage the post’s multiple independent reasons for higher substitutability; so it weakens confidence rather than refuting the claim (strength ~0.35). It is mostly correct: both sides are extrapolating beyond observed regimes, and “max speed” intuitions are indeed speculative; minor overstatement is that we’ve “never observed” even 10× more researchers (there is some variation), but the intended point (not orders-of-magnitude variation, not superintelligent researchers) stands. Clear, focused, and minimal fluff.
title: Extrapolation skepticism is applied selectively to empirical estimates but not armchair intuitions
